entry.title: Kickstart Your Developer Journey ‚Äì Get SAP-Certified in Low-Code/No-Code
entry.content:
New to development? No problem! SAP offers a certification and learning resources that help you build real business apps, workflows, and user experiences ‚Äî without needing to be a coding expert. Using tools like SAP Build Apps, Work Zone, and Process Automation, you‚Äôll be surprised how much you can do just by dragging, dropping, and configuring.

 

Simple Steps to Get Certified

 

Step 1: Learn at Your Own Pace Follow these beginner-friendly learning paths:

  • SAP Build Apps: Build apps visually without needing to write code. Learn how to connect data, create user-friendly pages, and define app behavior.
  • SAP Build Work Zone: Set up a digital workspace where users can access their apps and content in one place.
  • SAP Build Process Automation: Learn how to build simple workflows and automation tools to save time and reduce manual work.

Step 2: Practice What You Learn You‚Äôll try a real-world simulation using everything you‚Äôve learned. This hands-on practice is required before taking the certification exam and helps boost your confidence.

Step 3: Take the Certification Exam Once you feel ready, book your exam. Passing it proves your skills and gives you an official SAP Certification ‚Äî a great addition to your resume!

 

Want to Keep Growing?

 

  • Watch tutorials on YouTube from SAP Developer Advocates.
  • Join local SAP CodeJam events to meet and learn from other developers.
  • Subscribe to SAP Learning Hub for more guided learning from SAP experts.

 

Whether you're starting your career or switching to tech, this certification is a great way to get hands-on with real business tools ‚Äî and build your future.

entry.title: Build, Configure, and Deploy SAP CAP Projects to the Cloud
entry.content:
üöÄA Comprehensive, Step-by-Step Guide to Creating and Deploying a Full CAP Application with SAP Fiori UI in SAP Business Application Studio

The Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model provided by SAP is a powerful, opinionated framework designed to streamline the process of building enterprise-grade services and applications that are scalable, extensible, and cloud-ready. In this extensive guide, we will delve deeply into each and every step required to build a full-fledged CAP project from scratch using SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), enhance it with a Fiori UI, and deploy the entire application stack to the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) on Cloud Foundry. This guide is structured with elaborate explanations for beginners and intermediate developers alike.

Prerequisites and Initial Setup

Before we begin, ensure you have a valid SAP BTP trial or productive account with appropriate entitlements, particularly for SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Build Work Zone, which are essential for running managed application routers and deploying HTML5 applications. You also need access to SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), which will serve as your cloud-based IDE for this project.

== 1. Creating a Dev Space in SAP Business Application Studio ==

  1. Open your browser and navigate to the SAP Business Application Studio.

  2. On the landing page, click on the "Create Dev Space" button, which will prompt you to select a template.

  3. From the available options, choose "Full-Stack Cloud Application" as it comes pre-configured with essential tools for CAP and Fiori development.

  4. Assign a recognizable name to your dev space, for example, cap-bookshop, to easily identify it later.

  5. Check the box labeled "SAP HANA Tools" to enable support for creating and managing HANA database artifacts.

  6. Click on "Create Dev Space" and wait patiently for the status of the space to change to "RUNNING."

  7. Once the dev space is up and running, click on it to launch the integrated development environment where you will build your application.

== 2. Provisioning a SAP HANA Cloud Instance ==

  1. Log in to the SAP BTP Cockpit using your credentials.

  2. Navigate into your global account and select the appropriate subaccount.

  3. Under the navigation pane, click on "Service Marketplace" to view the available services.

  4. Search for "SAP HANA Cloud" and click on it when it appears in the search results.

  5. Click on the "Create" button to begin provisioning a new HANA database instance.

  6. Choose the SAP HANA Database (ensure you do not select SAP HANA Cloud Tools).

  7. Sign-In with cloud foundry account and select your space from the dropdown
  8. Enter a unique name for the instance (e.g., hana), specify your required configurations, set an admin password.

  9. Administrator Section:

    • Administrator Username: Auto-filled as DBADMIN.

    • Administrator Password: Enter a secure password.

    • Confirm Password: Retype to confirm.
      üîêKeep in mind: Passwords for DBADMIN expire every 180 days, so set a reminder to change them before expiry.

  11. Configure SAP HANA Database Settings

    In this step, you'll define your database instance's technical specifications.

     

    • Available Memory Range:
      In the trial version, it's fixed at 16 GB.

    ‚ÑπÔ∏èNote: Trial accounts come with fixed configurations for memory and storage. For more flexibility, a commercial account is required.

  12. Network & Cloud Connector Configuration

    In this step, configure the network access and optionally enable the Cloud Connector if needed.

    Allow all IP addresses (Selected in this guide)
    Suitable for trial and development ‚Äî easiest for testing external tools.
  13. Click "Create" in final stage

  14. The provisioning process may take a few minutes to complete. Once done, your database will be ready for binding.

  15. (Important) Whenever trying to deploy or bind your service or application ensure HANA Cloud is Started and running

== 3. Creating a New CAP Project Using Terminal Commands ==

  1. Inside your running BAS dev space, open a new terminal window by navigating to the menu: Terminal ‚Üí New Terminal.

  2. Change the current directory to your desired workspace, typically located at /home/user/projects/:

cd /home/user/projects/

  1. Run the CAP project initialization command:

cds init bookshop
cd bookshop
 

  1. Your project will now have a structured directory layout containing essential folders such as db for data models, for services, app for UI modules (currently empty), and package.json which manages dependencies.

== 4. Modeling Data and Defining Services ==

4.1 Define the Data Model

Create a new CDS file in the db folder, typically named data-model.cds:

namespace my.bookshop;

entity Books {
  key ID    : Integer;
      title : String;
      author: String;
      stock : Integer;
}

4.2 Add Sample Data in CSV Format

Create a new CSV file inside the db/data directory named my.bookshop-Books.csv:

ID;title;author;stock
1;The Hobbit;J.R.R. Tolkien;15
2;Harry Potter;J.K. Rowling;30
3;The Alchemist;Paulo Coelho;20

4.3 Define a CAP Service

Inside the srv folder, create a service definition file named catalog-service.cds:

using my.bookshop from '../db/data-model';

service CatalogService {
  entity Books as projection on my.bookshop.Books;
}

== 5. Configuring for SAP HANA Deployment ==

CAP defaults to SQLite for local development, but to deploy on SAP BTP, you must configure it to use SAP HANA.

  1. Add HANA configuration for production:

cds add hana --for production

  1. Add hybrid setup (for both dev and prod compatibility):

cds add hana --for hybrid

  1. Generate a Multi-Target Application (MTA) descriptor:

cds add mta

  1. Install all necessary project dependencies:

npm install

== 6. Previewing Your CAP App Locally ==

To see how your app behaves locally, start the development server:

cds watch

The terminal will display a URL where your CAP service is accessible. Click the link to open a preview interface, which features a basic UI generated using Fiori Elements.

== 7. Adding a Managed Application Router ==

  1. Right-click on the mta.yaml file and select Create MTA Module from Template.

  2. Choose the Approuter Configuration template.

  3. Follow the wizard:

    • Use a Managed Approuter.

    • Name it samplerouter or another descriptive identifier.

    • Indicate that a Fiori UI will be added later.

  4. Finish the wizard to generate the approuter configuration, including a xs-security.json file.

== 8. Adding XSUAA for Authentication and Authorization ==

XSUAA is required for deploying CAP apps to Cloud Foundry with authentication support.

cds add xsuaa --for production
npm install

This updates your package.json and adds authentication requirements under the "requires" section.

== 9. Creating a SAP Fiori UI App ==

  1. Right-click mta.yaml ‚Üí Create MTA Module from Template.

  2. Choose SAP Fiori Application and select List Report Page as the template.

  3. In the Data Source step:

    • Select Local CAP Project

    • Pick the bookshop project

    • Choose the CatalogService (Node.js)

  4. Confirm Books as the main entity.

  5. Set module name (e.g., booksui), title, and namespace.

  6. Enable deployment options and FLP configuration.

  7. For deployment:

  8. Target: Cloud Foundry

  9.  

    • Destination: Local CAP Project API

    • Semantic Object: bookshop

    • Action: show

    • Title: Books

Finish the wizard to generate the UI module.

== 10. Deploying the Application to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry ==

10.1 Login to Cloud Foundry

Use the command palette:

CTRL + Shift + P ‚Üí CF: Login to Cloud Foundry

Provide the API endpoint, credentials, and select the correct organization and space.

10.2 Bind the HANA HDI Container

  1. Open the SAP HANA Projects panel in BAS.

          Bind to a HDI Container

         Select "+ Create a new service instance" 

  2. Click bookshop-db ‚Üí Bind ‚Üí Create new service instance.

  3. Name it bookshop-db and enable auto undeploy.

10.3 Build and Deploy the MTA Archive

 

Run the following in your terminal:

mbt build
cf deploy mta_archives/bookshop_1.0.0.mtar

This creates and deploys your application archive.

== 11. Verifying Deployment and Launching Your Fiori App ==

  1. In the BTP cockpit, go to Services ‚Üí Instances. You should see instances for the db, approuter, CAP service, and xsuaa.

  2. Go to HTML5 Applications (enabled via SAP Build Work Zone) and find your booksui app.

  3. Launch the app to see the same Fiori UI you previewed locally, now hosted on the cloud.

entry.title: Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations
entry.content:
Welcome back to our new blog series,  our previous blog series  delved into the intricacies of dynamic sequential approval workflows.

In this two-part series, my colleague @Adwait_Fadnavis  and I will explore some very critical business workflow  requirements  in detail using SAP Build Process Automation. 

Throughout this blog series, we will delve into the following critical business requirements:

Part 1 - Current Blog :Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We will demonstrate how to use various SAP Build Process Automation tools to solve real-time challenges effectively.

This blog post addresses this complex requirement with detailed step-by-step instructions. You'll learn how to ensure workflows advance smoothly, even with  approval condition utilizing various innovative latest features such as: Wait Step with API Triggering , Workflow Context update via API etc.

Business Context and Problem Statement

While working on multiple SAP Build Process Automation projects, we have faced situations where workflows only proceed if all departments or approvers approve them unanimously.

If any approver rejects the proposal, the entire workflow is rejected . This creates a need for a parallel approval process, adhering to an "all-or-nothing" requirement, which SAP's standard solutions do not support.

In a below sample procurement workflow, the request is created and submitted. Both the Department Manager and Finance Department must approve it simultaneously. If either rejects, the workflow is terminated.

If both approve, the request goes to the Executive for final approval. The Executive's decision determines whether the request is processed or terminated.

Dynamic Number of Parallel Approval
Technical Solutioning & Design

In this process, we will create two workflows using SAP Build Process Automation‚Äôs Low Code/No Code approach.

Let‚Äôs refer to these as Workflow A (main workflow) and Workflow B.

Workflow A( Main Workflow): This is the main workflow, triggered with all input parameters, responsible for the overall business process flow.

Workflow B(Secondary Workflow): This workflow handles the approval task. It receives the Approval ID, total number of levels, and current level. If the final approval is granted, it triggers a wait step API  in Workflow A to proceed to the next level. If more approvals are needed, it sends the Approval ID to the next level.

 
Technical Design Steps for Workflow A:
 
  1. Trigger Workflow: The workflow is initiated with input parameters.
  2. Decision Creation: A decision step is created to determine the number of approvals require. 

3. Script Task: This step determines the total number of approvals and the current approval level.

$.context.custom.doneapprovalcount = 0;
$.context.custom.currentcount = 0;
$.context.custom.subwfdefinationid = "Your Secondaray Workflow ID"; // replace with your secondary workflow id
$.context.custom.totalapprovalcount = $.context.decision_getAppprovers_1.Approvers.length;
$.context.custom.triggeredsubprocessids = [];
‚Äã
  • Condition Check: If the current level matches the total required approvals, A wait step will be created to wait for the completion. If not, Workflow B is triggered to initiate the approval task.

  • Trigger Workflow B: Workflow B sends the work item to the respective user for approval.
  • Wait Step API : This critical step waits for all parallel approvals to be completed. Once done, the dummy decision is triggered by Workflow B. This is very interesting and latest features
    1. Create a Wait Step with API as follows. After Deployment it will event will create the API End Point which will used to trigger from secondary workflow B .      
    2. Execution ID is the Parent Workflow ID.
    3. Upload the API specification and create the action for this
    4.  Also make sure to create the API key which will be used to trigger it from secondary workflow B.

Technical Design Steps for Workflow B  (Triggered via Workflow A)

  1. Trigger from Workflow A : Workflow B starts when Workflow A reaches a certain point to manage approval tasks separately and in parallel to the main workflow.

  2. Send Approval Task: The approval task is sent to the current level approver to obtain necessary approvals at each level before proceeding.
  3. On Approval: The system retrieves instance details and updates the approval count to keep track of completed approvals and update the workflow status.  
  4. sample code
$.context.custom.approvedcount = $.context.action_get_getV1WorkflowInstancesWorkflowInstanceIdContext_6.result.custom.doneapprovalcount + 1;
  • Check Count: The system checks if all required approvals are obtained:
    • If all approvals are done, the workflow proceeds to the next step.
    • If not all approvals are done This ensures the workflow only proceeds once all approvals are obtained
  •  Update Parent Workflow A Approval Action : increment the update count. created a custom action. If all the approvals not done, then update the approval count via custom action. (refer our previous blog how to create action for workflow API)   
  • Retrieve Task ID & Trigger Wait API trigger wait step ( API) in Workflow A to signal that the approval process is complete / Reject  and it can proceed.
    • Now come to most crucial part of the Development: Trigger the wait step via API
    • Created a custom action project  for the wait step api end point.
    • Here is the Input mapping for the API call. Needs to provide the API Key and Parent ID.
    • It will trigger the wait step in workflow A to approve / move forward the workflow . 
 
In the upcoming blog post - Demonstration with complete end to end testing  , @Adwait_Fadnavis  will delve into the complete end to end testing for these which is very critical to understand the whole development flow.
 
Stay tuned for a comprehensive guide that will enhance your understanding and streamline your Development  process.

Regards,

Mohit Bansal,

SAP Mentor. SAP BTP Solution Architect

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build: Highlights from SAP Sapphire 2025
entry.content:
As the SAP Sapphire 2025 global keynote outlined, this year's focus was clear: AI, applications, and data. SAP Build continues to evolve in alignment with these themes, helping organizations efficiently build, automate, and extend their business processes and applications.

Here's a roundup of Sapphire's key SAP Build announcements and innovations to watch this year.

Joule Studio: Intelligent AI Agents and Skills Builder

Joule Studio Capabilities

SAP unveiled Joule Studio, a new environment within SAP Build that helps you create, deploy, and manage AI agents and custom skills. With Joule Studio, teams can enrich Joule with company-specific skills and intelligent agents that work across SAP and third-party systems. Joule Studio brings two powerful capabilities:

  • Joule Skills: Design modular, reusable skills that can be invoked during conversations. These skills can trigger actions, pull data, and orchestrate SAP Build components like workflows, automations, or apps.
  • AI Agents: Go beyond skills by building full-fledged AI agents that dynamically execute business tasks using reasoning capabilities. These agents use business context, data from SAP systems, and large language models to adapt to user needs.

Joule Studio will be available by the end of Q2 2025, with Agent Builder capabilities expected in Q4 2025.

Early adopters like Sovanta, an SAP partner, already use Joule Studio to enhance customer service. Sovanta significantly streamlined support processes and accelerated ticket resolution by integrating conversational skills with SAP systems.

Another early adopter, Pricefx - a global leader in cloud-based pricing software - is using Joule Studio to bring AI-driven intelligence into their solution. By developing an Agentic AI copilot, they aim to deliver contextual, business-aware guidance that enhances pricing decisions for their customers.

Interested in learning more? Register for the webcast: Meet Joule Studio: Drive Innovation with AI Agents & Joule Skills.

New AI Capabilities for Business Users and Developers

  • SAP Build Work Zone + Joule: Employees can now use Joule to find relevant apps, tasks, and documents faster. It can summarize or generate content based on your business data, saving time and boosting productivity.

Joule in SAP Build Work Zone

  • AI-Enhanced ABAP Development: Developers migrating to SAP Cloud ERP can use AI to convert custom ECC code into ABAP Cloud standards. This feature simplifies modernization efforts while ensuring code quality and compliance.

These capabilities are expected in Q3 2025.

 Expanded SAP Build Capabilities

SAP Build continues to grow as a unified platform with:

  • Extensibility Wizard for SAP Business Suite: A guided wizard that helps you build side-by-side extensions with the proper context, faster. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP SuccessFactors support is planned for release in H2 of 2025.

Extensibility Wizard in SAP Business Suite

Watch Sapphire Customer Session: Extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Build at OGE: Open Grid Europe used SAP Build to extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud‚Äîboosting onboarding efficiency by 50% and reducing invoicing time by 20%.

Watch Sapphire Solution Demo: Extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud: SAP Build application development and automation. Discover how to rapidly personalize and extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud while maintaining a clean core.

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Integration: Planned for Q4 2025, SAP Build will offer deep integration with SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) via CAP. Developers can consume and expose data products using virtual tables in SAP HANA Cloud, accelerating the development of insight-rich apps while reducing manual integration work. This improves data consistency and supports scalable, compliant development.
  • Event-Driven Applications: SAP Build, in combination with SAP Integration Suite and CAP, will support event-based interactions across systems. General availability is expected in H2 2025.

Simplified Pricing and Packaging

  • SAP Build offers a unified pricing model that combines app development, automation, and workspaces under a single entitlement. This simplifies adoption, reduces licensing complexity, and allows teams to build and extend at their own pace. Learn more in this blog post.

Thanks for reading! Which SAP Build innovation are you most excited about? Let us know - and don't miss these key resources from SAP Sapphire 2025:

  • Watch Sapphire Global Keynote: Your Best. Made Real. No Matter What Lies Ahead
  • Read SAP Sapphire 2025 Innovation Guide
  • Visit the Session Catalog with On-Demand Sessions

entry.title: Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
SAPUI5 is a cornerstone of SAP's user interface technology, providing a robust framework for building responsive and enterprise-ready web applications. Regular updates to SAPUI5 bring innovative features and critical bug fixes, ensuring that applications remain modern and efficient. Until now, the latest SAPUI5 versions were automatically adopted in production environments, which limited opportunities for early evaluation ahead of deployment.

Recognizing the need for controlled testing of SAPUI5 updates, we have introduced a new feature that allows administrators to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. This capability was developed in response to customer feedback, aiming to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments.

What's New: SAPUI5 Version Preview Feature in SAP Build Work Zone

The new "Preview SAPUI5 Latest Version" feature empowers administrators to test upcoming SAPUI5 versions in designated non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. This proactive approach allows customers to explore upcoming updates in a controlled setting, supporting a smoother and more predictable transition to production environments.

This feature is available in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and standard edition and SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone.

Key Benefits:

This feature offers several advantages. Administrators can gain early access to the Release to Customer (RTC) version of SAPUI5. They have two weeks before its general availability, allowing ample time for testing. By enabling the preview setting on specific non-productive sites, they can assess compatibility and performance with the upcoming version. This controlled testing environment helps identify and address potential issues, reducing the likelihood of disruptions in production. After the two-week preview period, the RTC version becomes the default, aligning all sites with the latest stable release.

How it works ‚Äì step by step

1. Enable Preview:

In the site editor, administrators can activate the "Preview SAPUI5 Latest Version" setting for selected non-productive sites.

Toggle turned off in site settings

Toggle turned on in site settings

Warning message while saving the changes 

Site preview on and further information

Site directory with a site where preview is turned on

2. Testing Period

The designated sites will consume the RTC version of SAPUI5 for a two-week period, during which thorough testing and validation can be conducted.

To enable this in SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, customers can create a dedicated site in their existing PROD or PRE-PROD sub-accounts (or QA, if preferred), there is no need to create a new sub-account. The relevant content can be transported to this test site, where the preview option for SAPUI5 can then be enabled. In SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, customer must setup a new sub-account (pre-prod) to use the UI5 preview feature.

3. Adjustment Option

If needed during the preview period, administrators can turn off the preview setting to revert the site back to the previously active version.

4. Automatic Update

After the two-week period, the RTC version becomes the default version for all sites, ensuring consistency across environments.

SAPUI5 versions

SAPUI5 provides new versions regularly to deliver innovative features and also to provide patches with bug fixes. See What's New in SAPUI5 and the SAPUI5 What's New Viewer to learn about the new features and Versioning and Maintenance of SAPUI5 to understand the versioning concept. A new version is consumed by default by SAP BTP services like SAP Build Work Zone to have a solid basis for new capabilities and an up-to-date user experience.

Approximately 2 weeks before a new version is consumed by SAP cloud solutions, it is released to customers (RTC). In this timeframe you may now test a new version with SAP Build Work Zone. Learn about the planned SAPUI5 versions with their planned RTC date in SAP Note 3504933.

Learn More! 

Important references:

  • See the planned SAPUI5 versions with their planned release date in SAP Note 3504933.
  • See the released SAPUI5 versions in SAPUI5 Versions Maintenance Status.

For more insights into SAPUI5 and SAP Build Work Zone:

  • Explore the SAPUI5: What's New and When Is It Coming? blog post on the SAP Community
  • SAP Build Work Zone on: sap.com / SAP Community
  • SAP Application Development and Automation Community Group

entry.title: Mastering SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations , Part 2
entry.content:
In our previous blog post, "Mastering Complex Approvals: A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations," my colleague & SAP Mentor @mohit_bansal3  tackled a common but challenging business requirement: the "all-or-nothing" approval process.

Part 1 - Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Current Blog : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We explored how SAP Build Process Automation, leveraging features like Wait Steps with API Triggering and workflow context updates via API, can handle scenarios where multiple approvals are needed simultaneously, and a single rejection stops the entire workflow.

We walked through a procurement example where both Department Managers and the Finance Department had to unanimously approve a request before it could proceed.

Now, in this second blog, we will demonstrate the step-by-step testing process for the solution we developed. This will allow you to understand the entire development flow more deeply, from concept to validation. Let's dive into the testing for the previous blog's implementation!

Handling Approval Outcomes: Positive and Negative Scenarios

The "All-or-Nothing" Positive Scenario : Lets Start the complete Testing Process

Let's first explore the "positive scenario," where every approver gives their stamp of approval. In this ideal outcome, once all required approvals are secured, the main workflow successfully completes its designated task. This seamless progression is the goal of our "All-or-Nothing" design, ensuring that every necessary check is performed before finalization.

Approval Process Triggering
As you know from our previous blog, for demonstration purposes, we created a simple form within SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA). 

 

Main process upon submission of request: Context and log  

You'll notice two approvers listed, which will initiate two parallel workflows. We covered the specifics of these parallel workflows in a previous blog post. The determination of these approvers can come from a decision table or your own custom logic.

The key takeaway here is that we've dynamically fetched two approvers, demonstrating the adaptable nature of this step.  it can handle any number of approvers.

 

 

Dynamically Triggering Secondary Workflows

We're now kicking off secondary workflows dynamically, and the number of these workflows depends entirely on the number of approvers.

For our current scenario, since we have two approvers, this process will trigger two parallel secondary workflows.

Each of these workflows will then send an individual approval request directly to each approver's My Inbox.

Dynamically Secondary Workflow Triggered via API

My Inbox View
Here's a quick look at My Inbox. For this demonstration, we've assigned the same approver.

That's why you see two work items in this approver's inbox. In a real-world scenario, these would be two separate workflow approval items, each in the respective approver's inbox.

Crucially, the main workflow won't complete until both approvals are in.

 

Workflow Progress After First Approval
The screenshot below shows the workflow log after the first approver has taken action. As you can see, the workflow isn't complete yet; it's waiting for the second secondary workflow to be actioned.

The main workflow will only move forward once both approvals are done.

But before we get ahead of ourselves, let's examine the workflow log immediately after that initial approvals.

 

Updating the Main Workflow Context after each approval:  SBPA API used as action
We'll be updating the main workflow's context after each approval and then comparing it against the total required count.

Here's a quick glimpse of what happens to the workflow context once the first approval is complete.

You can see the "donecount" increasing, which we'll use to compare against the total number of approvals needed.

We achieve this by updating the main workflow via its API, a process we've already covered in a previous blog post.

 

The Final Approval and Workflow Completion
Now, let's go a step deeper and understand the flow when the second, and final, approver takes action.

Once they approve, you'll see that the secondary workflow also completes, which then triggers the wait step in the main workflow.

This wait step is triggered via an API, a process we covered in detail in a previous blog post.

Understanding this particular use case of the wait step with an API is a critical aspect of this blog's core message.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Workflow Context After All Approvals
Now, let's carefully examine how the workflow context gets updated once all approvals are complete.

This is the crucial step that triggers the wait step and allows our main workflow to proceed.

In this scenario, the "donecount" becomes equal to the total number of required approvals, which in turn triggers the wait step API.

 

Handling Approval Outcomes: Positive and Negative Scenarios

so far We've explored the "positive scenario," where all approvers green-light the requests, leading to the main workflow's successful completion.

But what happens when an approver rejects a request?

Imagine a scenario where just one approver rejects. In such a case, the entire workflow must be rejected. My colleague, Mohit Bansal, detailed the design considerations for this rejection scenario in a previous blog post, so from a testing perspective, the approach remains similar.

However, in a rejection scenario, we need to take crucial additional steps:

  • Call the workflow cancel API: This immediately stops the main workflow.
  • Cancel any remaining open instances of secondary workflows: This is critical for designing a robust, production-ready complex workflow. Without canceling these, you could have orphaned workflow instances consuming resources or causing confusion.

     

  • Here's a quick look at how the system responds when any approver rejects: the main workflow is canceled, and all remaining open secondary workflow instances are also terminated.

We hope you enjoyed our blog series! We dove deep into complex workflow approval scenarios, exploring how to effectively leverage wait steps and workflow APIs to achieve robust "all-or-nothing" approval processes.

Please feel free to leave comments and share your thoughts. A big thank you to my colleague @mohit_bansal3  for his contributions, and stay tuned for more blogs on the latest innovations in this area!

Regards,

Adwait Fadnavis

entry.title: Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update
entry.content:
In this blog, I will introduce the new features that we have released so far in 2025, with version V2.2 and our latest version V2.3.
When SAP Mobile Start got launched in August 2021, the app got automatically provisioned with SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. In 2023, we added SAP Start and with the release V.2.2, SAP Mobile Start also connects to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.

When using SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you can now access your advanced edition content, like Workspaces or Feed Updates. As with the standard edition, your native and web apps are available within the Apps Screen of SAP Mobile Start, as well as in your Favorites Section on the Start Screen, based on your individual selection. This allows you direct and fast access to your business content while being mobile. 
What about the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition tasks and notifications? If you have set up the Alert Notification Service and SAP Task Center Service, then you find them next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center of SAP Mobile Start.

Screenshot: Notification Center with advanced edition notifications

We are looking forward to seeing many SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition and SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone customers to onboard to SAP Mobile Start, as it is automatically available if the SAP Mobile Start ‚Äútoggle‚Äù is enabled in the Site Manager.

Remark: SAP Mobile Start is not the successor app for the SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app. SAP Mobile Start focuses on providing users easy access to their applications and business workflows. The app is deeply integrated into the device OS and provides native push notifications and widgets to ensure a best-in-class user experience. The SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app focuses more on the collaboration aspects. Users can use both apps in parallel. Please also see our respective knowledge base article for further details. 

Besides seeing your latest open To-Dos in SAP Mobile Start, you can now also see your completed To-Dos. Just tap the ‚ÄúCompleted‚Äù filter button on the To-Do Screen and you will get your completed to-dos from the last six months right on the To-Dos Screen. You can also search across all open and completed to-dos via the search function.

Screenshot: Completed To-Dos

My favorite new feature is the site switch that is available with V2.3. This feature allows you to directly switch between SAP Build Work Zone sites. This is very helpful for IT teams but also for business users who work with multiple SAP Build Work Zone instances. Instead of always having to go through the complete onboarding process, the app offers you a list of recently used sites and you can just pick the one you need. Outdated sites can be deleted from your list with an easy swipe to the left. I am sure that you will love this feature.

Screenshots: Site Switch

Another nice enhancement comes for the news tiles. With the latest release of SAP Mobile Start, your news tile can also include news images. Furthermore, news feeds that require authentication are supported as well with the latest release. You just need to maintain the authenticated URL in the tile news property field ‚Äúmobilestart.feedUrl‚Äù in the site manager. Please have a look at our SAP Help documentation for details.

Screenshots: News with Image

You can now see the source system name on the app tiles with the latest release, what is very helpful if you have for instance connected multiple SAP S/4HANA systems to SAP Build Work Zone. The system name helps you to easily identify the system that is behind the tile. To use this feature, you can enable it in the Site Manager (‚ÄúDisplay: Show Source System Name on Tiles‚Äù).

Finally, the latest release provides some nice UX enhancements, like the enhanced navigation bar for Apple iPad and a new fresher design for monitoring details on Apple Watch. When you onboard to the app for the first time, a new in-app guide introduces the app features to you. In the Profile and Settings screen, you can now find detailed information about language settings for the app and for the displayed content; furthermore the app is now available in Hungarian.

Screenshot: New watch design 

I hope you will enjoy those new features in SAP Mobile Start.

For further information on the new topics, please check our SAP Mobile Start documentation.

SAP Mobile Experience offers intelligent native mobile solutions that help businesses build more efficient, resilient and sustainable end-to-end processes, improving people‚Äôs work life wherever they are.

Visit SAP Mobile Experience Community Page and click ‚Äúfollow‚Äù to get the latest development and innovation of our solutions. We look forward to hearing about your experience with setting up the solution in your landscape; please do share your thoughts and comments below. Enter here for additional questions regarding SAP Mobile Experience Applications.

entry.title: Unlocking the Future: How SAP Build Stands Out in Application Development
entry.content:
SAP Build stands out in the application development market due to its unique combination of low-code/no-code capabilities, deep integration with SAP ecosystems, AI-driven features, and focus on enterprise-grade scalability and governance. Below is a detailed analysis of why SAP Build differentiates itself from competitors like OutSystems, Mendix, or Microsoft Power Apps, emphasizing its strengths in the context of digital transformation and application development.

1. Unified Low-Code/No-Code Platform

  • Comprehensive Suite: SAP Build integrates three core components‚ÄîSAP Build Apps, SAP Build Process Automation, and SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîinto a single platform, enabling end-to-end development of applications, process automation, and business sites. Unlike competitors that often focus on one aspect (e.g., app development or automation), SAP Build provides a holistic solution, reducing the need for multiple tools.
  • Citizen Developer Empowerment: Its intuitive drag-and-drop interface and prebuilt templates allow business users with minimal technical expertise to create enterprise-grade applications. This democratizes development, enabling faster prototyping and reducing dependency on specialized developers, which competitors like OutSystems also offer but with less seamless SAP integration.

Standout Factor: The unified platform lowers the learning curve and streamlines workflows, making it ideal for businesses seeking rapid development without fragmented toolsets.

2. Deep Integration with SAP Ecosystem

  • SAP BTP Foundation: Built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Build seamlessly integrates with SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and other SAP solutions. This ensures a single source of truth, real-time data access, and compatibility with SAP‚Äôs clean core strategy, which minimizes technical debt during upgrades.
  • Extensibility: The Extensibility Wizard (introduced at SAP TechEd 2024) simplifies customization for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and is planned for SAP SuccessFactors, enabling tailored solutions without complex coding. Competitors like Mendix or Salesforce Lightning require additional integration layers to achieve similar SAP connectivity.
  • Third-Party Integration: SAP Build supports integration with non-SAP systems (e.g., Salesforce, Microsoft Dynamics) via SAP Integration Suite, with event-driven architecture planned for Q4 2025, enhancing real-time data flows.

Standout Factor: Native integration with SAP systems and support for hybrid environments make SAP Build the preferred choice for organizations heavily invested in SAP, unlike general-purpose platforms that require custom connectors.

3. AI-Driven Innovation

  • Joule Studio: SAP Build leverages AI through Joule Studio, enabling the creation of AI agents for predictive analytics, process automation, and intelligent decision-making. For example, it can automate complex workflows like invoice matching or predict inventory needs, a feature less prevalent in platforms like Appian or ServiceNow.
  • Embedded Intelligence: Integration with SAP AI Core allows developers to embed machine learning models into applications, enhancing functionality like demand forecasting or anomaly detection without external tools.
  • Natural Language Processing: Joule‚Äôs conversational AI simplifies user interactions, making app development and process automation accessible to non-technical users.

Standout Factor: AI-driven capabilities, tightly integrated with SAP‚Äôs enterprise data, provide a competitive edge over platforms with generic AI tools, delivering context-aware solutions for business-specific challenges.

4. Enterprise-Grade Scalability and Governance

  • Scalability: Built on SAP BTP‚Äôs cloud infrastructure, SAP Build supports enterprise-scale deployments with high availability and performance. It handles large-scale transformations, such as SAP S/4HANA migrations, with minimal latency, unlike smaller platforms like Bubble, which are better suited for startups.
  • Governance and Compliance: SAP Build includes built-in governance frameworks ensuring GDPR, SOC 2, and other compliance standards, critical for industries like finance or healthcare. This contrasts with platforms like Zoho Creator, which may require additional configurations for enterprise compliance.
  • Clean Core Strategy: SAP Build aligns with RISE with SAP‚Äôs clean core principles, ensuring extensions are upgradable and maintainable, reducing long-term costs compared to platforms like OutSystems, where customizations can lead to technical debt.

Standout Factor: Robust governance and scalability make SAP Build a trusted choice for large enterprises with complex regulatory and scalability needs.

5. Rapid Time-to-Value

  • Accelerated Development: SAP Build‚Äôs low-code approach reduces development time by 50-70% compared to traditional coding, as seen in case studies like Open Grid Europe, which achieved 50% faster onboarding using SAP Build Apps. Prebuilt templates and reusable components further speed up deployment.
  • Process Automation: SAP Build Process Automation combines RPA and workflow management, reducing manual tasks by up to 80% (e.g., financial close processes). This is faster than competitors like UiPath, which focus primarily on RPA without integrated app development.
  • Guided Methodologies: Integration with SAP Activate and SAP Signavio ensures structured implementation, minimizing project risks and accelerating time-to-value.

Standout Factor: The combination of low-code development, automation, and guided methodologies delivers faster ROI, particularly for SAP-centric transformations, compared to platforms with longer setup times.

6. Enhanced Collaboration and User Experience

  • Business-IT Collaboration: SAP Build bridges the gap between business and IT teams through shared development environments and visual tools, reducing miscommunication. For example, business users can prototype apps, while IT ensures governance, unlike Mendix, where IT involvement is often heavier.
  • SAP Build Work Zone: Provides role-based, personalized portals with SAP Fiori integration, improving user adoption by 25-40% (SAP benchmarks). This contrasts with platforms like Microsoft Power Apps, which offer less tailored UX for SAP environments.
  • Community and Support: SAP‚Äôs global partner ecosystem (e.g., EY, AG) and SAP Community provide extensive training and support, ensuring successful adoption compared to smaller platforms with limited ecosystems.

Standout Factor: Enhanced collaboration and user-centric design drive higher adoption rates, making SAP Build ideal for organizations prioritizing user engagement.

7. Competitive Positioning

Compared to key competitors:

  • OutSystems: Strong in low-code but lacks deep SAP integration and clean core alignment.
  • Mendix: Offers robust low-code features but requires more effort for SAP connectivity and compliance.
  • Microsoft Power Apps: Excels in Microsoft ecosystems but is less optimized for SAP environments.
  • ServiceNow: Focuses on IT service management, with limited app development flexibility compared to SAP Build‚Äôs comprehensive suite.

SAP Build‚Äôs tight integration with SAP BTP, AI capabilities, and focus on enterprise needs give it an edge for organizations leveraging SAP systems or pursuing large-scale digital transformations.

8. Real-World Impact

  • Open Grid Europe: Extended SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Build, achieving 50% faster onboarding and 20% reduced invoicing time.
  • Multinational Manufacturer: Used SAP Build with EY to standardize processes, improving efficiency across functions within 12 months.
  • Utilities Sector: Leveraged SAP Build for metering and billing apps, reducing process steps and enhancing real-time visibility.

Conclusion

SAP Build stands out in the application development market due to its unified low-code/no-code platform, deep SAP integration, AI-driven innovation, and enterprise-grade scalability. Its ability to accelerate development, automate processes, and ensure compliance while fostering collaboration makes it a leader for organizations undergoing SAP-centric or hybrid digital transformations. For businesses invested in SAP ecosystems or seeking rapid, scalable solutions, SAP Build delivers unmatched value, positioning it as a top choice in the competitive low-code market.

SAP Build  SAP AI Services SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: Application Frontend Service now generally available in SAP BTP Trail Account [cf us10-XXX]
entry.content:
As part of our exciting  SAP Build release, we're happy to announce the release of Application Frontend service, a new SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Trail account for US region for hosting, serving and operating frontend applications.

SAP BTP Trial accounts can be deployed with limited to five(5) applications per subaccount.

Now, you can enjoy the following benefits of Application Frontend Service

What is Application Frontend Service?

Host, serve, and manage frontend applications to extend SAP business solutions.

Application Frontend service lets you host and serve frontend applications. It serves as a single entry point for hosting web-based UI applications to extend SAP's business solutions. The service provides tools for deploying and managing applications, serving static resources, routing backend calls to defined targets, and observability tools.

Application Frontend service is included in the SAP Build.

Application Frontend service supports various channels for managing applications, such as the commonly used Generic Application Content Deployer (GACD) for multitarget applications (MTA), a dedicated UI in the cockpit, and a CLI. These options allow you to choose the channel that best suits your needs.

Application Frontend is a SaaS application which is not coupled to any specific SAP BTP runtime environment or other SAP BTP applications. You can find and subscribe to the service from the SAP BTP cockpit. Application Frontend is also equipped with a service broker to support interaction flows using service instances, for example when using MTA deploy in the CF environment. 

While there is native support in the good old MTA concept for lifecycle management, Application Frontend also provides a command line interface (CLI) as a first-class tool for managing your applications. With the CLI, you can directly interact with the service and execute all actions supported by Application Frontend to enjoy fast response times and new integration opportunities.

High Level Overview of Application Frontend Service - Deployment

Prerequisites to enable Application Frontend Serivce

  • Go to your SAP BTP Trail Account - Subaccount
  • Go to your Instance and Subscription - Subscribe for SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Enable SAP IAS and Trust & Auth with enabled SAP IAS
  • Go to Entitlements - Select Application Frontend Service
  • Select 2 checkbox for enabling the Plan (Developer and Application) 
  • Create a Role Collections and Assign to your User (SAP IAS enabled)

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service from dropdown with Plan - Trial

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service with Plan - Developer

Create a New Role Collection

Assign Role to newly created Role Collection

Application Frontend Service Library & CLI (Command Line)

npm install -g /appfront-cli

afctl login --sso -a <api_endpoint>

afctl push

 

Conclusion

Application Frontend Service is a game-changer for Cloud Foundry users. By simplifying UI development, enhancing scalability, and promoting consistency, AFS empowers developers to create high-quality applications more efficiently. As cloud-native development continues to evolve, integrating tools like AFS will be crucial in staying ahead of the curve and delivering exceptional user experiences.

For more detailed insights, you can check out the original blog posts : 

  • Introducing Application Frontend Service : Application Frontend Service 
  • Simple UI Applications with Application Frontend Service : DEV Community
  • Application Frontend Service Help Documentation : Guide and Development
  • Application Frontend Service Onboarding Service -  AppFront trial on-boarding help page

entry.title: A Comprehensive Guide to Transition from SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition to advanced edition
entry.content:
As organizations evolve, the need for more integrated digital workplace solutions becomes paramount. SAP Build Work Zone offers two distinct editions to cater to varying organizational needs: the standard edition and the advanced edition. While the standard edition provides a centralized access point to multiple SAP systems, the advanced edition extends these capabilities by empowering business users. This guide aims to facilitate a seamless transition from the standard to the advanced edition, ensuring that your organization can fully harness the enhanced features of the advanced edition.

Understanding the Differences

Before embarking on the transition, it's essential to comprehend the key distinctions between the two editions to make the most of the expanded set of capabilities in advanced:

  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition: Formerly known as SAP Launchpad service, this edition provides a central access point to multiple SAP cloud and on-premise applications, processes & tasks via different ‚Äòapplication site‚Äô. It also offers different customization and extension capabilities. 

SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition extends the capabilities of the standard edition by empowering business users to create, manage, and publish their own content. It also offers a broader set of widgets for more flexible workpage building. Users can also create interactive communities, known as workspaces, with document access, discussion forums, knowledge base, task collaboration & more.

The following visual offers a more detailed comparison, expanded feature set of the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. 

Subscription and Service Plan differences

  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition is often bundled with certain SAP cloud solutions (such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud), providing a streamlined setup for foundational portal and page-building use cases. It supports both subscription-based and consumption-based licensing models, making it suitable for customers seeking fast onboarding with minimal complexity. You can find more details here.
  • On the other hand, SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition is a standalone, premium offering that unlocks enterprise-grade capabilities. It requires a separate license and subscription that follows a follows a consumption-based commercial model. Read more here.

Transition Steps

Transitioning from the standard to the advanced edition involves several critical steps: 

1. Assess current implementation

Begin by thoroughly evaluating your existing SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition setup. Document all active sites, pages, applications, and integrations. Identify any custom developments, branding elements, or specific configurations that are crucial for replication or adaptation in the advanced edition.

2. Plan the transition

Establish clear objectives for the transition, such as enhancing user engagement or improving content management. Engage key stakeholders, including IT teams, business users, and content creators, to gather requirements and address potential concerns.

3. Exporting content from standard edition

It's crucial to export your existing content from standard edition to facilitate a smooth transition to the advanced edition. In the Site Directory, select the desired site, click on 'More Options', and choose 'Export Site' to download the site and its content as a ZIP file. This export includes the site's structure, pages, and associated applications, ensuring that essential components are preserved for import into the advanced edition.

4. Set up the advanced edition environment

It is possible to subscribe to both SAP Build Work Zone, standard and advanced editions within the same subaccount. This makes it easier to set up the advanced edition without disrupting your current standard edition setup.

To get started, subscribe to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition through the SAP BTP Cockpit. Configure user authentication and provisioning using SAP Cloud Identity Services (Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning) to ensure secure and efficient user management.

Use the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition booster to automate many of the initial setup steps in your subaccount. In addition to the booster, advanced edition requires a set of 'configurator' steps to be completed. These are essential for enabling full functionality of the service (and are not required or present in the standard edition). These steps typically include setting up roles, permissions, and other advanced configurations tailored to the edition‚Äôs extended capabilities.

5. Content migration

Since there is no fully automated upgrade or migration flow from the standard to the advanced edition, manual intervention is required. To ease the transition, you can export most of the content from the standard edition and import it into the advanced edition. This process involves the following steps:

  • Exporting the necessary content from the standard edition (as described above)
  • Importing the content to advanced edition

This approach allows for optimization and restructuring where needed. Additionally, leveraging the advanced edition's capabilities, such as interactive workspaces and enhanced page-building tools, can enrich the user experience.

6. Reusing existing configurations

When subscribing to the advanced edition within the same subaccount, certain configurations can be seamlessly reused. BTP destinations, Cloud Connector configurations, and custom applications remain intact and do not require (full) reconfiguration.

If your organization utilizes a custom domain, this can significantly ease the transition from a user perspective. For example, a custom domain that previously pointed to your standard edition site can now be reconfigured to point to the new advanced edition site. This allows users to continue accessing the Work Zone through their existing bookmarks and saved links without disruption. It ensures continuity and minimizes confusion during the switch, while maintaining consistent access points throughout the transition.

7. Best practices

To ensure a smooth transition it's advisable to first perform all migration and configuration activities in a non-production environment, such as a development or testing subaccount. This approach allows for thorough testing, validation of configurations, and identification of potential issues without impacting the live production environment. Once the transition process has been successfully tested and refined in these lower environments, you can confidently replicate the steps in the production subaccount, minimizing the risk of disruptions to end-users.

8. Testing and validation

Conduct thorough User Acceptance Testing (UAT) with a group of end-users to ensure all functionalities work as intended and meet business requirements. Evaluate the system's performance under typical load conditions to identify and address any potential issues.

9. Change management

Develop and deliver training sessions to familiarize users with the new features and interfaces of the advanced edition. Provide documentation, FAQs, and support channels to assist users during the transition period.

10. Go-live

Execute the transition plan, ensuring minimal disruption to daily operations. Continuously monitor the system for any issues and gather user feedback to make necessary adjustments.

Conclusion

This transition can significantly enhance your organization's digital workplace capabilities. By following a structured approach and leveraging the advanced features, you can create a more engaging and efficient user experience. It can empower your teams with the tools they need to collaborate effectively and drive business success.

Hope this blogpost will support your transition journey. We‚Äôll be following up shortly with a detailed how-to guide to help you through the process. 

For more detailed information consider exploring the following:

  • SAP Help Portal: Getting Started with SAP Build Work Zone
  • SAP Build Work Zone on: sap.com / SAP Community
  • SAP Learning Journeys:  Implement and Administer SAP Build Work Zone

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q2 2025 - Release Highlights
entry.content:
Q2 brought a wave of innovations to SAP Build, including improvements across governance, integration and user experience. We also had several announcements in the spotlight at SAP Sapphire 2025 around new AI capabilities, unified pricing, and of course Joule Studio, which lets you create custom Joule skills and AI agents. In case you missed it, check out our roundup of key updates from SAP Sapphire and the announcement of Joule Studio.

If you‚Äôre interested in shaping the future of SAP Build, we‚Äôve introduced the SAP Build Discovery Initiative 2025. We‚Äôre looking for participants to meet with product teams, test early prototypes and bring your perspective to influence innovations from day one. Find more info here.

Now let‚Äôs dive into the Top 10 release innovations from Q2 2025!

Enhanced governance capabilities

1. Empowering business users to maintain rules through an application

In Process Automation projects, business users are often the content owners of decisions and the logic behind business rules. While the SAP Build Lobby is a powerful environment, it can also be challenging to navigate and maintain the content of separate artifacts. 

Now IT and dev teams can give business users access to decisions via a purpose-built application, which is opened in SAP Build Work Zone. By empowering business users to access the logic this way, it helps mitigate risks of unauthorized changes, while also reducing delays around the change management process.

Manage decisions through a purpose-built application

2. Improved governance with approval flows & multi-node project transport

Strong governance frameworks are essential to ensure that your development activities remain secure and compliant. We have now released two features that support greater control and quality assurance:

  • Governance approval flows: This enables administrators to control who is authorized to create or transport projects across tenants or sub-accounts. The approval process is fully customizable, allowing organizations to implement quality gates aligned with their specific governance and compliance requirements.
  • Multi-node project transport: Approvers can now move SAP Build projects (apps, processes, automations) through a controlled Dev -> Test -> Production landscape, with approval steps and quality checks at each stage. This ensures dev teams are moving projects securely and efficiently across tenants.

Governance approval flows

Seamless interoperability and AI-powered integration

3. Importing Business Process Model & Notation (BPMN) to generate process artifacts automatically 

Great news for our automation enthusiasts ‚Äì it‚Äôs now possible to import BPMN processes from other tools into SAP Build! BPMN is the industry standard for defining workflows, decisions, and interactions across systems and teams. 

Now process designers can migrate existing BPMN processes from SAP Signavio, SAP NetWeaver, and IBM to generate process artifacts automatically. This long-awaited transportability helps to speed up the logic creation significantly, as well as acting as the bridge between SAP Build and other process modeling tools. 

To get started with BPMN process imports, see the Help Portal.Import BPMN processes into SAP Build

4. Improved SAP SuccessFactors integration with event discovery

From the SAP Build Lobby, developers can manage and connect SAP and non-SAP systems through the Unified Customer Landscape (UCL). Now in the UCL, developers can discover business events from SAP Cloud Application Event Hub, as well as SAP SuccessFactors solutions. This improved integration supports more relevant scenarios for HR processes, such as employee onboarding and compensation management. 

5. AI grounding in company-specific content for tailored responses

This feature makes it possible to base Joule copilot and other embedded AI capabilities on up-to-date documents and user-created content in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition through the RAG (retrieval augmented generation) method. Rather than giving generic responses, it provides end users with more accurate and domain-specific content.

AI grounding within Joule copilot

6. Joule-based assistant to easily migrate SAP HANA applications to CAP

For simplified innovation across services, the SAP HANA Application Migration Assistant is a new extension available in SAP Build Code. This automates the conversion of XS classic applications into CAP-based services to accelerate modernization and help businesses adopt cloud-native architectures faster.

For more info, see Product Updates for SAP Build Code ‚Äì June 2025 Edition

Optimized user experience and accessibility across devices

7. SAP Mobile Start as the unified mobile access point for users

SAP Mobile Start addresses the challenge of fragmented access to enterprise applications and information for mobile users. The connection of SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition ensures that users have consistent and secure access to business applications, tasks, and notifications, regardless of their location or device.

 8. Preview SAPUI5 updates for better UX management

To address the need for more controlled testing, we‚Äôve introduced the ability to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. Admins can activate the preview in a staging or dev tenant, validate compatibility and confirm everything works as expected before go-live ‚Äì ensuring agile development, reduced downtime, and better user experience management.

For more info, read the blog post.

SAPUI5 version preview in SAP Build Work Zone

9. Local Entry Point (LEP) to simplify access to standalone sites

The new Local Entry Point (LEP) concept of SAP Build Work Zone simplifies how SaaS application providers integrate business solutions into SAP BTP. Providers can generate a standalone entry-point site in the consumer‚Äôs subaccount, eliminating the extra efforts and complexity required to set up their own instances.

To get started, see the Help Portal.

10. Updates to Mobile Development Kit for enhanced UI, APIs and more

The latest release to SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) has brought several new updates for customers, including the newest version of Mobile Services Client in the Google Play Store and Apple App Store. Among the newest enhancements to UI is support for donut charts, providing a new way to visualize data and emphasize different aspects of datasets.

See all the latest updates: What‚Äôs New in Mobile Development Kit client 25.6

Ready to see these in action?

To learn more and see live demos of the latest release highlights, join us for the next What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q2 2025 Webinar! 

üëâRegister for your preferred time slot:

  • July 17th, 9:00AM ‚Äì 10:00AM CEST: https://sap.to/60414diDL
  • July 17th, 5:00PM ‚Äì 6:00PM CEST: https://sap.to/60434diDF

entry.title: SAP Fiori Deployment in 2025: Embedded vs. Work Zone Standard vs. Advanced Edition
entry.content:
As SAP advances its strategy toward a unified and intelligent user experience, organizations are increasingly required to re-evaluate their SAP Fiori deployment models. Traditional architectures, such as the Central Hub, are being phased out in favor of more modern, cloud-based solutions like SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîavailable in both Standard and Advanced editions.

This shift presents a strategic decision point for IT leaders: selecting the most appropriate deployment model that aligns with their existing system landscape, integration needs, and long-term digital goals. Understanding the strengths and trade-offs of Embedded Fiori, Work Zone Standard, and Work Zone Advanced is essential for designing a scalable and user-centric enterprise environment.

This guide compares all three modern deployment approaches so you can make an informed, future-proof decision.

Option 1: Embedded Deployment (Frontend + Backend in S/4HANA)

What it is: Fiori frontend server and Launchpad are embedded directly into the SAP S/4HANA system.

Best for:

  • Greenfield S/4HANA implementations
  • Simpler landscapes with no need to federate apps from multiple sources

Pros:

  • Simplified architecture
  • Lower total cost of ownership
  • Direct and efficient performance
  • No additional BTP subscription needed

Cons:

  • Not ideal for hybrid system landscapes (e.g., ECC + S/4)
  • Downtime impacts entire stack
  • Limited flexibility for UI extensions or content aggregation

Option 2: SAP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition
(Successor to Central Hub deployment)

What it is: A cloud-based launchpad-as-a-service running on SAP BTP. Provides centralized access to apps and content from multiple SAP systems.

Best for:

  • Customers with hybrid environments (e.g., ECC, S/4HANA, CRM)
  • Users needing a unified Launchpad across systems

Pros:

  • Aggregates apps from multiple systems
  • Personalizable Launchpad (cards, themes, roles)
  • Prebuilt integration with SAP apps like Ariba, SuccessFactors, and Concur
  • Low-code extensibility with SAP Build tools
  • Lower entry point than Advanced edition

Cons:

  • Limited support for advanced workflows or custom page layouts
  • Less extensibility for 3rd-party or custom content
  • No native document management or microsite capabilities

Option 3: SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
(For full digital experience and enterprise portal replacement)

What it is: An enterprise-grade digital workplace platform built on SAP BTP + SAP Launchpad + SAP Work Zone + SAP Build Pages + SAP Knowledge Base. It replaces traditional SAP Enterprise Portal and delivers full-scale intranet functionality.

Best for:

  • Customers replacing SAP Enterprise Portal
  • Organizations needing to integrate SAP and non-SAP apps
  • Use cases requiring business content, collaboration, workflows, and knowledge-sharing

Pros:

  • Advanced page builder for intranet-like UX
  • Deep integration with Microsoft 365, Teams, SharePoint, and 3rd-party systems
  • Role-based content delivery with custom navigation layouts
  • Embedded SAP Task Center, Process Automation, Knowledge Base
  • Ideal for large, multi-LOB organizations

Cons:

  • Higher cost and complexity than Standard edition
  • Requires thoughtful implementation planning
  • Best suited for organizations with mature digital transformation goals

Comparison table:

 

AspectSAP Fiori LaunchpadSAP Work Zone Standard EditionSAP Work Zone Standard Edition
DeploymentOn S/4HANA systemSAP BTPSAP BTP
System Scope1 system (S/4HANA)Multiple SAP systemsSAP + 3rd-party apps
UX FlexibilityBasic LaunchpadLaunchpad + basic cardsFull page editor, custom layouts
CollaborationNoneNonewikis, forums, Teams
Document ManagementNoneNoneAvailable
Task Center / WorkflowNotification Area/Local Workflows (My Inbox)SAP Task CenterEmbedded SAP Task Center
M365 IntegrationNoneNoneAvailable
Use Case FitSimplicity & speedCentral accessFull digital workplace
Ideal ForS/4HANA-only landscapesHybrid SAP appsPortal replacement + collaboration
CostNo additional BTP costMediumHigher

Conclusion

Establishing a unified point of entry for enterprise users is essential to an effective SAP Fiori deployment strategy. Whether an organization operates within a single SAP S/4HANA system or manages a complex, multi-system landscape, selecting the appropriate deployment model ensures enhanced usability, simplified maintenance, and long-term adaptability.

Embedded Fiori is best suited for organizations running a clean, standalone SAP S/4HANA environment. It provides a streamlined, fully self-contained user experience without requiring integration with other SAP or non-SAP systems‚Äîmaking it an efficient and cost-effective option for focused landscapes.

SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì Standard Edition is recommended for scenarios involving multiple SAP backend systems, such as ECC, CRM, or BW. It serves as a centralized launchpad, delivering a consistent user experience across the enterprise.

SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì Advanced Edition is ideal for companies seeking to replace SAP Enterprise Portal or establish a robust digital workplace. With capabilities for cross-application integration, collaboration, document management, and connectivity to third-party platforms like Microsoft 365, it supports a modern and extensible enterprise UX.

SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîavailable in both Standard and Advanced Editions‚Äîrepresents the evolution of SAP‚Äôs UX strategy, replacing legacy frontend models with a cloud-native, scalable platform aligned with digital transformation goals.

Ultimately, the deployment choice should reflect the organization's current IT architecture, user requirements, and future roadmap. Aligning SAP Fiori strategy with these considerations enables a future-ready user experience that empowers employees and streamlines system management.

entry.title: We asked, you answered. Customer views on SAP BTP.
entry.content:
A little over three years ago the SAP BTP team decided to develop a review page for SAP BTP with Trust Radius, a leader in enterprise software reviews, so that we might capture some feedback directly from customers concerning their satisfaction with their investment in SAP BTP, and which we hoped would also include their thoughts about the effect that use of the platform and its services was having on their own businesses.

Having now surpassed over 500 reviews, and even more ratings, as well as collecting several awards on the way, including the recent ‚ÄúTop Rated 2025‚Äù award among others, I thought that now would be a good time to reflect on some of the feedback that customers have left in their reviews of SAP BTP. 

So, here‚Äôs the first of what I hope will be a series of blogs which will look at some of the reviews that customers have left with Trust Radius about their experience with SAP BTP.  And I‚Äôve decided to do this by taking a look from different organizational viewpoints, given that reviews have been left by individuals from various roles, in different parts of the business, and from organizations of all sizes.

SAP BTP in customers‚Äô words

Let‚Äôs start with reviews from different types and sizes of organizations, and in in our customers‚Äô own words here‚Äôs what they say:

‚Äú(Company) uses BTP to manage HTML applications that are then displayed in a customer and supplier portal, we also use BTP to manage users accessing the portal and all this connected to a S4/HANA‚Ä¶SAP Business Technology Platform is the right tool to manage sites, applications, users and everything you can imagine in the cloud and non-cloud world, from my point of view BTP is very well focused and has everything that a tool has to have and today‚Äù Large media production organization, 5*review, 10000+ employees, June 2025

‚ÄúSAP Business Technology Platform is being used in our organization ‚Ä¶It's low code/ no-code so easier to integrate HANA server with non-SAP server for data sync and rapid development of the product for the production. It helps us to get real time insight of data‚Ä¶we connected our SAP servers like mm, litmos to the legacy system we have like dynamics and salesforce, which helped us a lot during data migration and system integration. It helps the entire business automation process. Easier to analyze and manage the data with beautiful dashboard. After having this much still it's cost effective‚Äù Mid-sized engineering company 5* review, 501-1000 employees, April 2025

‚ÄúBTP is used to improvise customer experience and creating automated processes across line of business and also enhancing the data and for the advanced analytics for helping in better decision-making and also BTP is a key tool for enabling the digital transformation to achieve better integration for creating more value for data and seamless flow between SAP and non SAP applications‚Äù Large IT & services business 5* review, 1001-5000 employees, May 2025

Of course, these are just a few of many reviews hosted on the SAP BTP page on the Trust Radius platform, and my selection criteria was simply one of organizational size. But even within just this small sample of customer reviews, it‚Äôs clear that SAP BTP is being used for different use cases across these differing organizations, but still delivering value through integration, automation and analytics capabilities.

Next time I‚Äôll take a look from another viewpoint, but meanwhile, if you‚Äôre already intrigued and wish to see for yourself how customers are using SAP BTP then please feel free to browse the library of SAP BTP reviews on Trust Radius, or read more about SAP BTP on our website.

Happy reading!

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Simple End to End Application development using SAP Build App
entry.content:
Simple End to End Application development using SAP Build App

Developing extension apps is a very common requirement among clients. Using Fiori application as an extension to SAP BTP was always an option but we can use SAP‚Äôs no code/ low code to develop a basic UI application which will connected to SAP SuccessFactors instance.

We will be developing an application for email search (this is just a basic application).

In the below example, I have used trail BTP account.

SuccessFactors Connectivity

I have created a destination in my trail subaccount to connect to one of my sandbox SF tenants.

 

SAP Build App Configuration

  1. Create a project of type ‚Äì SAP Build Apps ‚Äì web & mobile application

 

 

 

 

 

 2. Once project is created successfully, navigate to auth and data tab to integrate with SAP SuccessFactors

 

Select SF credentials which is created in BTP destination.

 

Search the entity (PerEmail in our case) and click on install integration and enable it.

 

 3. Navigate back to UI Canvas and start design your web page

Drag heading, a text and two cards.

 

 

Change the label accordingly.

 

Select the text field and navigate to content -> formula and write as per below screenshot.

4. Now click on home page on left side and create new pages

 

5. Navigate back to home page -> select email search card -> add logic to card 1

In Properties, search the page on which we want to navigate. Similarly, do for view data card.

 

 

 

 6. Configure search Page

Drag two input fields, a button and a text field for showing output

 

 7. Define variables.

Switch to variables view and in page variables, create PersonId, EmailType and output

 

8. Populate the variables to UI

Select the personId input field and then click on value ->  data and variables -> page variables -> PersonId.

Similarly, do this for email type

 

 

 

 

9. Add logic on button.

In the logic canvas, search for get records and map with component tap. Select ‚Äòget records‚Äô and map the personId and email type variable

 

 

 

 

To populate the output of search in another page variable, map it with set page variable and bind with output of another node

 

 

 

 

 

10. Configure table

Navigate to database screen and add table by searching in the market place

 

 

Click

 

Click on edit configuration and select the fields required in the table

 

 

 

 

Now app is ready to test.

11. Launch and test the application

Click on Launch -> open preview portal -> preview on web

 

 

 

 

 

 

By using the capabilities of SAP build app, final application which I have built looks like below:

Summary: This document outlines the steps to build a basic end-to-end application using SAP Build Apps with a no-code/low-code approach. It demonstrates connecting to a SAP SuccessFactors instance and designing a UI for email search functionality. The app includes variable binding, logic flows, and result display, making it ready for testing through the preview portal. This approach simplifies extension app development on SAP BTP.

entry.title: Developing a Shell Plugin for SAP Build Work Zone to Display Custom Notifications on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction‚ÄÉ

Unlocking Custom Experiences in SAP Build Work Zone: Shell Plugin in Action
In today‚Äôs digital workplace, personalization is key. This article showcases how to enhance SAP Build Work Zone with a custom shell plugin that brings tailored notifications right to the user‚Äôs fingertips. Using a Multi-Target UI5/CAP application, we‚Äôll demonstrate how to create, manage, and surface custom alerts‚Äîseamlessly integrated into your Work Zone experience.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

To replicate this you should have a base knowledge of SAP BTP, JS, SAPUI5 and SAP CAP, I will not go deep down in to how to generate a project in BAS, or create an instance in SAP BTP. 

***GITHUB URL REMOVED BY MODERATION***

Project Architecture

‚ÄÉ

Backend/Frontend App Development:

Generate a regular SAP CAP application

Firstly I've created a primitave data structure under db/schema.cds

namespace my.Notification;

entity Notification {
    key ID : UUID;
    type: String(30);
    title: String;
    message: String;
}

 Than a service at srv/service.cds:

using { my.Notification as my } from '../db/schema';
